title: Richard Van Gelder
text:
Richard George Van Gelder (December 17, 1928 – February 23, 1994) was a prominent <a href="mammalogist">mammalogist</a> who served as the Curator of Mammalogy for the <a href="American%20Museum%20of%20Natural%20History">American Museum of Natural History</a> in New York for more than twenty-five years.
Career.
Among his accomplishments at the Museum of Natural History was the 1969 redesign of the Hall of Ocean Life featuring the blue whale which still hangs in the center of the hall. Among his colleagues in the Mammal Department at the AMNH were <a href="Karl%20Koopman">Karl Koopman</a>, Marie A. Lawrence, <a href="Guy%20Musser">Guy Musser</a>, and Sydney Anderson.
In 1957, while on the Puritan Expedition to the Baja Peninsula, he discovered a new species of <a href="vesper%20bat">vesper bat</a> commonly known as <a href="Van%20Gelder%27s%20Bat">Van Gelder's Bat</a>. His later research included the study of the <a href="nyala">nyala</a> in Mozambique. He was a President of the <a href="American%20Society%20of%20Mammalogists">American Society of Mammalogists</a> from 1968 to 1970.
He was the author of a number of mammalogy books including "Biology of Mammals" and "Mammals of the National Parks " as well as a large range of mammal related children's books such as "Bats", "Animals in Winter", "The Professor and the Mysterious Box", "The Professor and the Vanishing Flags", " Monkeys and Apes", and "Whose Nose Is This?" He died in 1994 of acute monocytic leukemia.
